newsitem.title: USA: The Simpsons, X-Files among 1997 Peabody winners.
newsitem.headline: The Simpsons, X-Files among 1997 Peabody winners.

text.p: Fox Television's "The Simpsons" and "The X-Files" were among this year's Peabody Award recipients for broadcast and cable excellence, award sponsors said Thursday.

ABC's "NYPD Blue" and NBC's "Law and Order" also were among winners of the 56th annual George Foster Peabody Awards from the University of Georgia's Henry W. Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communications.
The awards will be presented formally May 12 during a ceremony at New York's Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Six of the 31 Peabodys awarded this year went to Boston Public Broadcasting Service affiliate WGBH-TV for episodes of of the documentary series "Frontline," the science programme "NOVA," "The American Experience" and "Mobil Masterpiece Theatre."
Unlike other industry honours, the Peabody Awards are not given within designated categories and the number of awards varies from year to year.

Hollywood director Steven Spielberg received his second Peabody Award for the Turner Original Productions documentary "Survivors of the Holocaust." Judges noted his work in preserving the testimonies of Holocaust survivors.

Another winner was "The 14 Stories of Eric Morse," a National Public Radio documentary about the 1994 death of a Chicago youngster who was thrown from the 14th floor of a housing project by two other boys. The two reporters were 16-year-old project residents.
Award sponsors noted that "The Simpsons" still offered biting satire as social commentary after eight years.
"NYPD Blue" was described as having transcended other police dramas by confronting the conflicted circumstances of homicide officers in New York City.
Sponsors cited "The X-Files" for bringing new vitality to prime-time television entertainment, and noted "Law & Order" for its insights into core social issues.
